sentences.literal: Zhang Cang, the Chancellor, was a man from Yangwu.
He was fond of books, laws, and calendars.

sentences.chinese: 秦時為御史，主柱下方書。
sentences.literal: During Qin times he served as a censor in charge of the square books below the pillar.
He committed a crime and fled back home.

sentences.chinese: 及沛公略地過陽武，蒼以客從攻南陽。
sentences.literal: When the Duke of Pei was raiding territory and passed through Yangwu, Cang followed as a guest to attack Nanyang.

sentences.chinese: 蒼坐法當斬，解衣伏質，身長大，肥白如瓠，時王陵見而怪其美士，乃言沛公，赦勿斬。
sentences.literal: Cang was convicted by law and should be beheaded. He loosened his clothes and lay on the execution block. His body was tall and large, fat and white like a gourd. At the time Wang Ling saw him and marveled at this beautiful gentleman, so he spoke to the Duke of Pei, who pardoned him and did not behead him.
He then followed west through Wuguan and arrived at Xianyang.

sentences.chinese: 沛公立為漢王，入漢中，還定三秦。
sentences.literal: The Duke of Pei was established as King of Han, entered Hanzhong, and returned to settle the Three Qin.

sentences.chinese: 陳餘擊走常山王張耳，耳歸漢，漢乃以張蒼為常山守。
sentences.literal: Chen Yu struck and drove away Changshan king Zhang Er. Er returned to Han, and Han then made Zhang Cang Changshan governor.

sentences.chinese: 從淮陰侯擊趙，蒼得陳餘。
sentences.literal: He followed Marquis Huaiyin in striking Zhao, and Cang captured Chen Yu.

sentences.chinese: 趙地已平，漢王以蒼為代相，備邊寇。
sentences.literal: Once Zhao lands were pacified, the Han king made Cang chancellor of Dai to prepare against border bandits.

sentences.chinese: 已而徙為趙相，相趙王耳。
sentences.literal: Soon after he was moved to serve as chancellor of Zhao, chancellor to Zhao king Er.
Er died, and he served as chancellor to Zhao king Ao.
He was again moved to serve as chancellor to the Dai king.

sentences.chinese: 燕王臧荼反，高祖往擊之。
sentences.literal: Yan king Zang Tu rebelled, and Gaozu went to strike him.
